d108fc09519b74a17073da8f1accfe55 (02:07): okay heres another question about virtual desktop powertoy. is there anyway  i can have each desktop have it's own taskbar?
4ff7d9bab0006756de2051a298c80706 (02:07): IronGland, the same taskbar repeated?
d108fc09519b74a17073da8f1accfe55 (02:08): scratchme: yeah. whenever I switch desktops the taskbar stays the same. all the apps i have docked on it stay there between desktops
4ff7d9bab0006756de2051a298c80706 (02:08): That's what it does, or what you want it to do?

d108fc09519b74a17073da8f1accfe55 (02:09): i want each desktop to have their own taskbar so that i can organize my desktops. for example. internet in one desktop, visual studio in another, etc. etc. withouth having to see the buttons docked on the button of the screen for other apps

4ff7d9bab0006756de2051a298c80706 (02:11): Anyway, not aware of how to do what you want, but you could check litestep if it's still ongoing.

329f50925a14a3b6fe4c76a087dd5e7f (02:21): I the HDD in a back office PC die. It started up to "cannot find \windows\sytem32\config\system...." I tried copying \windows\repair\system over and was able to get the winxp splash screen but then the screen was just black. I ghosted the drive to a new drive using the "continue on bad blocks" switch. After complaining about unreadable sectors I did manage to complete the ghost. I tried ghosting this new drive before running chkdsk but it failed

329f50925a14a3b6fe4c76a087dd5e7f (02:21): until i ran chkdsk on it. Now, after running chdsk on this new drive with the old image, the system will not load. It complains "Windows could not start because of following ARC firmware boot configuration
329f50925a14a3b6fe4c76a087dd5e7f (02:21): problem: did not properly generate ARC name for HAL and system paths."
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (02:22): khanman, interesting. Is the new drive back in the original system?

329f50925a14a3b6fe4c76a087dd5e7f (02:24): i knew i was gonna need to run chkdsk on the new drive (with old image) so i tried to ghost the new drive after imaging it. Because i doubt if i will be able to ghost the original drive again
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (02:24): http://www.short-media.com/review.php?r=313
1e2bafed5050e07132cd7377a6bd4684 (02:24): when you set local user policy audits
1e2bafed5050e07132cd7377a6bd4684 (02:24): where are the audits stored
1e2bafed5050e07132cd7377a6bd4684 (02:24): event viewer?
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (02:25): yes
1e2bafed5050e07132cd7377a6bd4684 (02:25): does it specific its an audit?
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (02:25): auditing = event log
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (02:25): rather, security log
1e2bafed5050e07132cd7377a6bd4684 (02:26): quux how do i clear the logs
1e2bafed5050e07132cd7377a6bd4684 (02:26): in event viewer
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (02:26): In that same part of the MMC (audit polices) you will see about 10 different types of events that can be audited/logged
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (02:26): just rightclick the log in the lefthand pane
1e2bafed5050e07132cd7377a6bd4684 (02:26): yeah this guys getting brute forced a lot
1e2bafed5050e07132cd7377a6bd4684 (02:26): i set account lockouts etc
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (02:27): So you'll want to audit logon/logoff, definitely. The problem is that logon/logoff events show the computername, not an IP

329f50925a14a3b6fe4c76a087dd5e7f (02:27): quux, thx for the url ill give it a shot...reloading this PC will be a major pain in the A as im fairly certain that the client doesnt have all of the installation media nor even know what all was on it :)

5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (02:30): and which account is being attacked? ADMINISTRATOR?
1e2bafed5050e07132cd7377a6bd4684 (02:30): renamed
1e2bafed5050e07132cd7377a6bd4684 (02:30): this is via msftp
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (02:30): You'll find that this creates a lot of work for you
